segment.source: Create an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using Microsoft Intune (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using Microsoft Intune (Windows 10)

segment.source: Microsoft Intune helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.
segment.target: Microsoft Intune helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.

segment.source: Create an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using Microsoft Intune
segment.target: Create an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using Microsoft Intune

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Insider Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Insider Preview

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile Preview

segment.source: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]

segment.source: Microsoft Intune helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.
segment.target: Microsoft Intune helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.

segment.source: Important note about the June service update
segment.target: Important note about the June service update

segment.source: We've received some great feedback from you, our Windows 10 Insider Preview customers, about our enterprise data protection experiences and processes.
segment.target: We've received some great feedback from you, our Windows 10 Insider Preview customers, about our enterprise data protection experiences and processes.

segment.source: Because of that feedback, we're delighted to deliver an enhanced apps policy experience with the June service update.
segment.target: Because of that feedback, we're delighted to deliver an enhanced apps policy experience with the June service update.

segment.source: This means that when you open an existing enterprise data protection policy after we release the June service update in your test environment, your existing Windows 10 enterprise data protection app rules (formerly in the Protected Apps area) will be removed.
segment.target: This means that when you open an existing enterprise data protection policy after we release the June service update in your test environment, your existing Windows 10 enterprise data protection app rules (formerly in the Protected Apps area) will be removed.

segment.source: To prepare for this change, we recommend that you make an immediate backup of your current app rules as they are today, so you can use them to help reconfigure your app rules with the enhanced experience.
segment.target: To prepare for this change, we recommend that you make an immediate backup of your current app rules as they are today, so you can use them to help reconfigure your app rules with the enhanced experience.

segment.source: When you open an existing enterprise data protection policy after we release the June service update, you'll get a dialog box telling you about this change.
segment.target: When you open an existing enterprise data protection policy after we release the June service update, you'll get a dialog box telling you about this change.

segment.source: Click the OK button to close the box and to begin reconfiguring your app rules.
segment.target: Click the OK button to close the box and to begin reconfiguring your app rules.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Reconfigure app rules list dialog box
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Reconfigure app rules list dialog box

segment.source: Note that if you exit the Policy page before you've saved your new policy, your existing deployments won't be affected.
segment.target: Note that if you exit the Policy page before you've saved your new policy, your existing deployments won't be affected.

segment.source: However, if you save the policy without reconfiguring your apps, an updated policy will be deployed to your employees with an empty app rules list.
segment.target: However, if you save the policy without reconfiguring your apps, an updated policy will be deployed to your employees with an empty app rules list.

segment.source: Add an EDP policy
segment.target: Add an EDP policy

segment.source: After you’ve installed and set up Intune for your organization, you must create an EDP-specific policy.
segment.target: After you’ve installed and set up Intune for your organization, you must create an EDP-specific policy.

segment.source: To add an EDP policy
segment.target: To add an EDP policy

segment.source: Open the Intune administration console, and go to the Policy node, and then click Add Policy from the Tasks area.
segment.target: Open the Intune administration console, and go to the Policy node, and then click Add Policy from the Tasks area.

segment.source: Go to Windows, click the Enterprise Data Protection (Windows 10 and Mobile and later) policy, pick the EDP template, click Create and Deploy a Custom Policy, and then click Create Policy.
segment.target: Go to Windows, click the Enterprise Data Protection (Windows 10 and Mobile and later) policy, pick the EDP template, click Create and Deploy a Custom Policy, and then click Create Policy.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Create your new policy from the New Policy screen
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Create your new policy from the New Policy screen

segment.source: Type a name (required) and an optional description for your policy into the Name and Description boxes.
segment.target: Type a name (required) and an optional description for your policy into the Name and Description boxes.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Fill out the required Name and optional Description fields
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Fill out the required Name and optional Description fields

segment.source: Add individual apps to your Protected App list
segment.target: Add individual apps to your Protected App list

segment.source: During the policy-creation process in Intune, you can choose the apps you want to give access to your enterprise data through EDP.
segment.target: During the policy-creation process in Intune, you can choose the apps you want to give access to your enterprise data through EDP.

segment.source: Apps included in this list can protect data on behalf of the enterprise and are restricted from copying or moving enterprise data to unprotected apps.
segment.target: Apps included in this list can protect data on behalf of the enterprise and are restricted from copying or moving enterprise data to unprotected apps.

segment.source: The steps to add your apps are based on the type of app it is; either a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, or a signed Desktop app, also known as a Classic Windows application.
segment.target: The steps to add your apps are based on the type of app it is; either a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, or a signed Desktop app, also known as a Classic Windows application.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: EDP-aware apps are expected to prevent enterprise data from going to unprotected network locations and to avoid encrypting personal data.
segment.target: EDP-aware apps are expected to prevent enterprise data from going to unprotected network locations and to avoid encrypting personal data.

segment.source: On the other hand, EDP-unaware apps might not respect the corporate network boundary and will encrypt all files they create or modify, meaning that they could encrypt personal data and cause data loss during the revocation process.
segment.target: On the other hand, EDP-unaware apps might not respect the corporate network boundary and will encrypt all files they create or modify, meaning that they could encrypt personal data and cause data loss during the revocation process.

segment.source: Care must be taken to get a support statement from the software provider that their app is safe with EDP before adding it to your Protected App list.
segment.target: Care must be taken to get a support statement from the software provider that their app is safe with EDP before adding it to your Protected App list.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you want to use File hash or Path rules, instead of Publisher rules, you must follow the steps in the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic.
segment.target: If you want to use File hash or Path rules, instead of Publisher rules, you must follow the steps in the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic.

segment.source: To add a UWP app
segment.target: To add a UWP app

segment.source: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.
segment.target: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.

segment.source: Click Universal App, type the Publisher Name and the Product Name into the associated boxes, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Universal App, type the Publisher Name and the Product Name into the associated boxes, and then click OK.

segment.source: If you don't have the publisher or product name, you can find them for both desktop devices and Windows 10 Mobile phones by following these steps.
segment.target: If you don't have the publisher or product name, you can find them for both desktop devices and Windows 10 Mobile phones by following these steps.

segment.source: To find the Publisher and Product name values for Microsoft Store apps without installing them
segment.target: To find the Publisher and Product name values for Microsoft Store apps without installing them

segment.source: Go to the Windows Store for Business website, and find your app.
segment.target: Go to the Windows Store for Business website, and find your app.

segment.source: For example, Microsoft OneNote.
segment.target: For example, Microsoft OneNote.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If your app is already installed on desktop devices, you can use the AppLocker local security policy MMC snap-in to gather the info for adding the app to the Protected App list.
segment.target: If your app is already installed on desktop devices, you can use the AppLocker local security policy MMC snap-in to gather the info for adding the app to the Protected App list.

segment.source: For info about how to do this, see the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic.
segment.target: For info about how to do this, see the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic.

segment.source: Copy the ID value from the app URL.
segment.target: Copy the ID value from the app URL.

segment.source: For example, Microsoft OneNote's ID URL is https://www.microsoft.com/store/apps/onenote/9wzdncrfhvjl, and you'd copy the ID value, .
segment.target: For example, Microsoft OneNote's ID URL is https://www.microsoft.com/store/apps/onenote/9wzdncrfhvjl, and you'd copy the ID value, .

segment.source: In a browser, run the Store for Business portal web API, to return a JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) file that includes the publisher and product name values.
segment.target: In a browser, run the Store for Business portal web API, to return a JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) file that includes the publisher and product name values.

segment.source: For example, run https://bspmts.mp.microsoft.com/v1/public/catalog/Retail/Products/9wzdncrfhvjl/applockerdata, where 9wzdncrfhvjl is replaced with your ID value.
segment.target: For example, run https://bspmts.mp.microsoft.com/v1/public/catalog/Retail/Products/9wzdncrfhvjl/applockerdata, where 9wzdncrfhvjl is replaced with your ID value.

segment.source: The API runs and opens a text editor with the app details.
segment.target: The API runs and opens a text editor with the app details.

segment.source: Copy the value into the Publisher Name box and copy the value into the Product Name box of Intune.
segment.target: Copy the value into the Publisher Name box and copy the value into the Product Name box of Intune.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The JSON file might also return a value for both the Publisher Name and Product Name boxes.
segment.target: The JSON file might also return a value for both the Publisher Name and Product Name boxes.

segment.source: This means that you have an app that’s using a XAP package and that you must set the Product Name as , and set the Publisher Name as “CN=” followed by the .
segment.target: This means that you have an app that’s using a XAP package and that you must set the Product Name as , and set the Publisher Name as “CN=” followed by the .

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Add a UWP app to the Protected Apps list
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Add a UWP app to the Protected Apps list

segment.source: To find the Publisher and Product name values for apps installed on Windows 10 Mobile phones
segment.target: To find the Publisher and Product name values for apps installed on Windows 10 Mobile phones

segment.source: If you need to add mobile apps that aren't distributed through the Store for Business, you must use the Windows Device Portal feature.
segment.target: If you need to add mobile apps that aren't distributed through the Store for Business, you must use the Windows Device Portal feature.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Your PC and phone must be on the same wireless network.
segment.target: Your PC and phone must be on the same wireless network.

segment.source: On the Windows Phone, go to Settings, choose Update & security, and then choose For developers.
segment.target: On the Windows Phone, go to Settings, choose Update & security, and then choose For developers.

segment.source: In the For developers screen, turn on Developer mode, turn on Device Discovery, and then turn on Device Portal.
segment.target: In the For developers screen, turn on Developer mode, turn on Device Discovery, and then turn on Device Portal.

segment.source: Copy the URL in the Device Portal area into your device's browser, and then accept the SSL certificate.
segment.target: Copy the URL in the Device Portal area into your device's browser, and then accept the SSL certificate.

segment.source: In the Device discovery area, press Pair, and then enter the PIN into the website from the previous step.
segment.target: In the Device discovery area, press Pair, and then enter the PIN into the website from the previous step.

segment.source: On the Apps tab of the website, you can see details for the running apps, including the publisher and product names.
segment.target: On the Apps tab of the website, you can see details for the running apps, including the publisher and product names.

segment.source: Start the app for which you're looking for the publisher and product name values
segment.target: Start the app for which you're looking for the publisher and product name values

segment.source: Copy the value and paste it into the Publisher Name box and the value into the Product Name box of Intune.
segment.target: Copy the value and paste it into the Publisher Name box and the value into the Product Name box of Intune.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The JSON file might also return a value for both the Publisher Name and Product Name boxes.
segment.target: The JSON file might also return a value for both the Publisher Name and Product Name boxes.

segment.source: This means that you have an app that’s using a XAP package and that you must set the Product Name as , and set the Publisher Name as “CN=” followed by the .
segment.target: This means that you have an app that’s using a XAP package and that you must set the Product Name as , and set the Publisher Name as “CN=” followed by the .

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: To add a Classic Windows application
segment.target: To add a Classic Windows application

segment.source: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.
segment.target: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.

segment.source: A dialog box appears, letting you pick whether the app is a Universal App or a Desktop App.
segment.target: A dialog box appears, letting you pick whether the app is a Universal App or a Desktop App.

segment.source: Click Desktop App, pick the options you want (see table), and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Desktop App, pick the options you want (see table), and then click OK.

segment.source: Option
segment.target: Option

segment.source: Manages
segment.target: Manages

segment.source: All fields left as "*"
segment.target: All fields left as "*"

segment.source: All files signed by any publisher.
segment.target: All files signed by any publisher.

segment.source: (Not recommended.)
segment.target: (Not recommended.)

segment.source: Publisher selected
segment.target: Publisher selected

segment.source: All files signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: All files signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: This might be useful if your company is the publisher and signer of internal line-of-business apps.
segment.target: This might be useful if your company is the publisher and signer of internal line-of-business apps.

segment.source: Publisher and Product Name selected
segment.target: Publisher and Product Name selected

segment.source: All files for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: All files for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, and File Name selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, and File Name selected

segment.source: Any version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Any version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, Exactly selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, Exactly selected

segment.source: Specified version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Specified version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And above selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And above selected

segment.source: Specified version or newer releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Specified version or newer releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: This option is recommended for enlightened apps that weren't previously enlightened.
segment.target: This option is recommended for enlightened apps that weren't previously enlightened.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And below selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And below selected

segment.source: Specified version or older releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Specified version or older releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: If you’re unsure about what to include for the publisher, you can run this PowerShell command:
segment.target: If you’re unsure about what to include for the publisher, you can run this PowerShell command:

segment.source: Where goes to the location of the app on the device.
segment.target: Where goes to the location of the app on the device.

segment.source: For example, .
segment.target: For example, .

segment.source: In this example, you'd get the following info:
segment.target: In this example, you'd get the following info:

segment.source: Where the text, is the publisher name to enter in the Publisher Name box.
segment.target: Where the text, is the publisher name to enter in the Publisher Name box.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Add a Classic Windows app to the Protected Apps list
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Add a Classic Windows app to the Protected Apps list

segment.source: Exempt apps from EDP restrictions
segment.target: Exempt apps from EDP restrictions

segment.source: If you're running into compatibility issues where your app is incompatible with EDP, but still needs to be used with enterprise data, you can exempt the app from the EDP restrictions.
segment.target: If you're running into compatibility issues where your app is incompatible with EDP, but still needs to be used with enterprise data, you can exempt the app from the EDP restrictions.

segment.source: This means that your apps won't include auto-encryption or tagging and won't honor your network restrictions.
segment.target: This means that your apps won't include auto-encryption or tagging and won't honor your network restrictions.

segment.source: It also means that your exempted apps might leak.
segment.target: It also means that your exempted apps might leak.

segment.source: To exempt an UWP app
segment.target: To exempt an UWP app

segment.source: Follow the Add a UWP app steps in the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic, through to Step 11.
segment.target: Follow the Add a UWP app steps in the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic, through to Step 11.

segment.source: In the OMA-URI box at Step 12, type .
segment.target: In the OMA-URI box at Step 12, type .

segment.source: Where edpexempt is added as a substring, making the app exempt.
segment.target: Where edpexempt is added as a substring, making the app exempt.

segment.source: Open File Explorer, go to the location where you saved your new XML file, and open it using an XML editor, such as Notepad.
segment.target: Open File Explorer, go to the location where you saved your new XML file, and open it using an XML editor, such as Notepad.

segment.source: Copy the text that has a Type of Appx, within in the RuleCollection tags, and then go back to Intune and paste the text into the Value box of the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box.
segment.target: Copy the text that has a Type of Appx, within in the RuleCollection tags, and then go back to Intune and paste the text into the Value box of the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Click OK to close the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box, and then click Save Policy.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box, and then click Save Policy.

segment.source: After saving the policy, you’ll need to deploy it to your employee’s devices.
segment.target: After saving the policy, you’ll need to deploy it to your employee’s devices.

segment.source: For more info, see the Deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy topic.
segment.target: For more info, see the Deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy topic.

segment.source: To exempt a Classic Windows application
segment.target: To exempt a Classic Windows application

segment.source: Follow the Add a Classic Windows application app steps in the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic, through to Step 11.
segment.target: Follow the Add a Classic Windows application app steps in the Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list topic, through to Step 11.

segment.source: In the OMA-URI box at Step 12, type .
segment.target: In the OMA-URI box at Step 12, type .

segment.source: Where edpexempt is added as a substring, making the app exempt.
segment.target: Where edpexempt is added as a substring, making the app exempt.

segment.source: Open File Explorer, go to the location where you saved your new XML file, and open it using an XML editor, such as Notepad.
segment.target: Open File Explorer, go to the location where you saved your new XML file, and open it using an XML editor, such as Notepad.

segment.source: Copy the text that has a Type of EXE, within in the RuleCollection tags, and then go back to Intune and paste the text into the Value box of the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box.
segment.target: Copy the text that has a Type of EXE, within in the RuleCollection tags, and then go back to Intune and paste the text into the Value box of the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Click OK to close the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box, and then click Save Policy.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box, and then click Save Policy.

segment.source: After saving the policy, you’ll need to deploy it to your employee’s devices.
segment.target: After saving the policy, you’ll need to deploy it to your employee’s devices.

segment.source: For more info, see the Deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy topic.
segment.target: For more info, see the Deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy topic.

segment.source: Manage the EDP protection level for your enterprise data
segment.target: Manage the EDP protection level for your enterprise data

segment.source: After you've added the apps you want to protect with EDP, you'll need to apply a management and protection mode.
segment.target: After you've added the apps you want to protect with EDP, you'll need to apply a management and protection mode.

segment.source: We recommend that you start with Silent or Override while verifying with a small group that you have the right apps on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: We recommend that you start with Silent or Override while verifying with a small group that you have the right apps on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: After you're done, you can change to your final enforcement policy, either Override or Block.
segment.target: After you're done, you can change to your final enforcement policy, either Override or Block.

segment.source: Mode
segment.target: Mode

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Block
segment.target: Block

segment.source: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing practices and stops the employee from completing the action.
segment.target: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing practices and stops the employee from completing the action.

segment.source: This can include sharing info across non-enterprise-protected apps in addition to sharing enterprise data between other people and devices outside of your enterprise.
segment.target: This can include sharing info across non-enterprise-protected apps in addition to sharing enterprise data between other people and devices outside of your enterprise.

segment.source: Override
segment.target: Override

segment.source: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing, warning employees if they do something deemed potentially unsafe.
segment.target: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing, warning employees if they do something deemed potentially unsafe.

segment.source: However, this management mode lets the employee override the policy and share the data, logging the action to your audit log, accessible through the Reporting CSP.
segment.target: However, this management mode lets the employee override the policy and share the data, logging the action to your audit log, accessible through the Reporting CSP.

segment.source: Silent
segment.target: Silent

segment.source: EDP runs silently, logging inappropriate data sharing, without blocking anything that would’ve been prompted for employee interaction while in Override mode.
segment.target: EDP runs silently, logging inappropriate data sharing, without blocking anything that would’ve been prompted for employee interaction while in Override mode.

segment.source: Unallowed actions, like apps inappropriately trying to access a network resource or EDP-protected data, are still blocked.
segment.target: Unallowed actions, like apps inappropriately trying to access a network resource or EDP-protected data, are still blocked.

segment.source: Off
segment.target: Off

segment.source: EDP is turned off and doesn't help to protect or audit your data.
segment.target: EDP is turned off and doesn't help to protect or audit your data.

segment.source: After you turn off EDP, an attempt is made to decrypt any closed EDP-tagged files on the locally attached drives.
segment.target: After you turn off EDP, an attempt is made to decrypt any closed EDP-tagged files on the locally attached drives.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Add the protection level for your Protected Apps list
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Add the protection level for your Protected Apps list

segment.source: Define your enterprise-managed identity domains
segment.target: Define your enterprise-managed identity domains

segment.source: Specify your company’s enterprise identity, expressed as your primary internet domain.
segment.target: Specify your company’s enterprise identity, expressed as your primary internet domain.

segment.source: For example, if your company is Contoso, its enterprise identity might be contoso.com.
segment.target: For example, if your company is Contoso, its enterprise identity might be contoso.com.

segment.source: The first listed domain (in this example, contoso.com) is the primary enterprise identity string used to tag files protected by any app on the Protected App list.
segment.target: The first listed domain (in this example, contoso.com) is the primary enterprise identity string used to tag files protected by any app on the Protected App list.

segment.source: You can also specify all the domains owned by your enterprise that are used for user accounts, separating them with the "|" character.
segment.target: You can also specify all the domains owned by your enterprise that are used for user accounts, separating them with the "|" character.

segment.source: For example, if Contoso also has some employees with email addresses or user accounts on the fabrikam.com domain, you would use contoso.com|fabrikam.com.
segment.target: For example, if Contoso also has some employees with email addresses or user accounts on the fabrikam.com domain, you would use contoso.com|fabrikam.com.

segment.source: This list of managed identity domains, along with the primary domain, make up the identity of your managing enterprise.
segment.target: This list of managed identity domains, along with the primary domain, make up the identity of your managing enterprise.

segment.source: User identities (user@domain) that end in any of the domains on this list, are considered managed.
segment.target: User identities (user@domain) that end in any of the domains on this list, are considered managed.

segment.source: To add your primary domain
segment.target: To add your primary domain

segment.source: Type the name of your primary domain into the Primary domain field.
segment.target: Type the name of your primary domain into the Primary domain field.

segment.source: For example, contoso.com.
segment.target: For example, contoso.com.

segment.source: If you have multiple domains, you must separate them with the "|" character.
segment.target: If you have multiple domains, you must separate them with the "|" character.

segment.source: For example, .
segment.target: For example, .

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Add the primary internet domain for your enterprise identity
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Add the primary internet domain for your enterprise identity

segment.source: Choose where apps can access enterprise data
segment.target: Choose where apps can access enterprise data

segment.source: After you've added a protection mode to your apps, you'll need to decide where those apps can access enterprise data on your network.
segment.target: After you've added a protection mode to your apps, you'll need to decide where those apps can access enterprise data on your network.

segment.source: There are no default locations included with EDP, you must add each of your network locations.
segment.target: There are no default locations included with EDP, you must add each of your network locations.

segment.source: This area applies to any network endpoint device that gets an IP address in your enterprise’s range and is also bound to one of your enterprise domains, including SMB shares.
segment.target: This area applies to any network endpoint device that gets an IP address in your enterprise’s range and is also bound to one of your enterprise domains, including SMB shares.

segment.source: Local file system locations should just maintain encryption (for example, on local NTFS, FAT, ExFAT).
segment.target: Local file system locations should just maintain encryption (for example, on local NTFS, FAT, ExFAT).

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Every EDP policy should include policy that defines your enterprise network locations.
segment.target: Every EDP policy should include policy that defines your enterprise network locations.

segment.source: Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation isn’t supported for EDP configurations.
segment.target: Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation isn’t supported for EDP configurations.

segment.source: To specify where your protected apps can find and send enterprise data on the network
segment.target: To specify where your protected apps can find and send enterprise data on the network

segment.source: Add additional network locations your apps can access by clicking Add, typing a description into the Description box, and then choosing your location type, including:
segment.target: Add additional network locations your apps can access by clicking Add, typing a description into the Description box, and then choosing your location type, including:

segment.source: Network location type
segment.target: Network location type

segment.source: Format
segment.target: Format

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Enterprise Cloud Resources
segment.target: Enterprise Cloud Resources

segment.source: With proxy:
segment.target: With proxy:

segment.source: contoso.sharepoint.com,proxy.contoso.com|
segment.target: contoso.sharepoint.com,proxy.contoso.com|

segment.source: contoso.visualstudio.com,proxy.contoso.com
segment.target: contoso.visualstudio.com,proxy.contoso.com

segment.source: Without proxy:
segment.target: Without proxy:

segment.source: contoso.sharepoint.com|contoso.visualstudio.com
segment.target: contoso.sharepoint.com|contoso.visualstudio.com

segment.source: Specify the cloud resources to be treated as corporate and protected by EDP.
segment.target: Specify the cloud resources to be treated as corporate and protected by EDP.

segment.source: For each cloud resource, you may also optionally specify an internal proxy server that routes your traffic through your Enterprise Internal Proxy Server.
segment.target: For each cloud resource, you may also optionally specify an internal proxy server that routes your traffic through your Enterprise Internal Proxy Server.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the "|" delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the "|" delimiter.

segment.source: If you don’t use proxy servers, you must also include the "," delimiter just before the "|".
segment.target: If you don’t use proxy servers, you must also include the "," delimiter just before the "|".

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: If Windows is unable to determine whether an app should be allowed to connect to a network resource, it will automatically block the connection.
segment.target: If Windows is unable to determine whether an app should be allowed to connect to a network resource, it will automatically block the connection.

segment.source: If instead you want Windows to allow the connections to happen, you can add the string to this setting.
segment.target: If instead you want Windows to allow the connections to happen, you can add the string to this setting.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Enterprise Network Domain Names
segment.target: Enterprise Network Domain Names

segment.source: domain1.contoso.com,domain2.contoso.com
segment.target: domain1.contoso.com,domain2.contoso.com

segment.source: Specify the DNS suffixes used in your environment.
segment.target: Specify the DNS suffixes used in your environment.

segment.source: All traffic to the fully-qualified domains appearing in this list will be protected.
segment.target: All traffic to the fully-qualified domains appearing in this list will be protected.

segment.source: This setting works with the IP ranges settings to detect whether a network endpoint is enterprise or personal on private networks.
segment.target: This setting works with the IP ranges settings to detect whether a network endpoint is enterprise or personal on private networks.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the "," delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the "," delimiter.

segment.source: Enterprise Proxy Servers
segment.target: Enterprise Proxy Servers

segment.source: domain1.contoso.com:80;
segment.target: domain1.contoso.com:80;

segment.source: domain2.contoso.com:137
segment.target: domain2.contoso.com:137

segment.source: Specify your externally-facing proxy server addresses, along with the port through which traffic is allowed and protected with EDP.
segment.target: Specify your externally-facing proxy server addresses, along with the port through which traffic is allowed and protected with EDP.

segment.source: This list shouldn’t include any servers listed in the Enterprise Internal Proxy Servers list, which are used for EDP-protected traffic.
segment.target: This list shouldn’t include any servers listed in the Enterprise Internal Proxy Servers list, which are used for EDP-protected traffic.

segment.source: This setting is also required if you use a proxy in your network.
segment.target: This setting is also required if you use a proxy in your network.

segment.source: If you don't have a proxy server, you might find that enterprise resources are unavailable when a client is behind a proxy, such as when you’re visiting another company and not on that company’s guest network.
segment.target: If you don't have a proxy server, you might find that enterprise resources are unavailable when a client is behind a proxy, such as when you’re visiting another company and not on that company’s guest network.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the ";" delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the ";" delimiter.

segment.source: Enterprise Internal Proxy Servers
segment.target: Enterprise Internal Proxy Servers

segment.source: proxy1.contoso.com;
segment.target: proxy1.contoso.com;

segment.source: proxy2.contoso.com
segment.target: proxy2.contoso.com

segment.source: Specify the proxy servers your devices will go through to reach your cloud resources.
segment.target: Specify the proxy servers your devices will go through to reach your cloud resources.

segment.source: Using this server type indicates that the cloud resources you’re connecting to are enterprise resources.
segment.target: Using this server type indicates that the cloud resources you’re connecting to are enterprise resources.

segment.source: This list shouldn’t include any servers listed in the Enterprise Proxy Servers list, which are used for non-EDP-protected traffic.
segment.target: This list shouldn’t include any servers listed in the Enterprise Proxy Servers list, which are used for non-EDP-protected traffic.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the ";" delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must separate them using the ";" delimiter.

segment.source: Enterprise IPv4 Range
segment.target: Enterprise IPv4 Range

segment.source: Starting IPv4 Address: 3.4.0.1
segment.target: Starting IPv4 Address: 3.4.0.1

segment.source: Ending IPv4 Address: 3.4.255.254
segment.target: Ending IPv4 Address: 3.4.255.254

segment.source: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv4 value range within your intranet.
segment.target: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv4 value range within your intranet.

segment.source: These addresses, used with your Enterprise Network Domain Names, define your corporate network boundaries.
segment.target: These addresses, used with your Enterprise Network Domain Names, define your corporate network boundaries.

segment.source: If you have multiple ranges, you must separate them using the "," delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple ranges, you must separate them using the "," delimiter.

segment.source: Enterprise IPv6 Range
segment.target: Enterprise IPv6 Range

segment.source: Starting IPv6 Address: 2a01:110::
segment.target: Starting IPv6 Address: 2a01:110::

segment.source: Ending IPv6 Address: 2a01:110:7fff:ffff:
segment.target: Ending IPv6 Address: 2a01:110:7fff:ffff:

segment.source: ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff
segment.target: ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff

segment.source: Custom URI: 2a01:110::-2a01:110:7fff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff,
segment.target: Custom URI: 2a01:110::-2a01:110:7fff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff,

segment.source: fd00::-fdff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff
segment.target: fd00::-fdff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff

segment.source: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv6 value range within your intranet.
segment.target: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv6 value range within your intranet.

segment.source: These addresses, used with your Enterprise Network Domain Names, define your corporate network boundaries.
segment.target: These addresses, used with your Enterprise Network Domain Names, define your corporate network boundaries.

segment.source: If you have multiple ranges, you must separate them using the "," delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple ranges, you must separate them using the "," delimiter.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Choose the primary domain and the other network locations for protected apps
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Choose the primary domain and the other network locations for protected apps

segment.source: Add as many locations as you need, and then click OK.
segment.target: Add as many locations as you need, and then click OK.

segment.source: The Add or Edit Enterprise Network Locations box closes.
segment.target: The Add or Edit Enterprise Network Locations box closes.

segment.source: In the Use a data recovery certificate in case of data loss box, click Browse to add a data recovery certificate for your policy.
segment.target: In the Use a data recovery certificate in case of data loss box, click Browse to add a data recovery certificate for your policy.

segment.source: After you create and deploy your EDP policy to your employees, Windows will begin to encrypt your corporate data on the employees’ local device drive.
segment.target: After you create and deploy your EDP policy to your employees, Windows will begin to encrypt your corporate data on the employees’ local device drive.

segment.source: If somehow the employees’ local encryption keys get lost or revoked, the encrypted data can become unrecoverable.
segment.target: If somehow the employees’ local encryption keys get lost or revoked, the encrypted data can become unrecoverable.

segment.source: To help avoid this possibility, the Data Recovery Agent (DRA) certificate lets Windows use an included public key to encrypt the local data, while you maintain the private key that can unencrypt the data.
segment.target: To help avoid this possibility, the Data Recovery Agent (DRA) certificate lets Windows use an included public key to encrypt the local data, while you maintain the private key that can unencrypt the data.

segment.source: For steps about how to create and verify an EFS DRA certificate, see the Create and verify an Encrypting File System (EFS) DRA certificate section of this topic.
segment.target: For steps about how to create and verify an EFS DRA certificate, see the Create and verify an Encrypting File System (EFS) DRA certificate section of this topic.

segment.source: For more info about how to find and export your data recovery certificate, see the Data Recovery and Encrypting File System (EFS) topic.
segment.target: For more info about how to find and export your data recovery certificate, see the Data Recovery and Encrypting File System (EFS) topic.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Specify a data recovery certificate for your policy
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Specify a data recovery certificate for your policy

segment.source: Create and verify an Encrypting File System (EFS) DRA certificate
segment.target: Create and verify an Encrypting File System (EFS) DRA certificate

segment.source: If you don’t already have an EFS DRA certificate, you’ll need to create and extract one from your system before you can use EDP in your organization.
segment.target: If you don’t already have an EFS DRA certificate, you’ll need to create and extract one from your system before you can use EDP in your organization.

segment.source: For the purposes of this section, we’ll use the file name EFSDRA; however, this name can be replaced with anything that makes sense to you.
segment.target: For the purposes of this section, we’ll use the file name EFSDRA; however, this name can be replaced with anything that makes sense to you.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: If you already have an EFS DRA certificate for your organization, you can skip creating a new one.
segment.target: If you already have an EFS DRA certificate for your organization, you can skip creating a new one.

segment.source: Just use your current EFS DRA certificate in your policy.
segment.target: Just use your current EFS DRA certificate in your policy.

segment.source: To add your EFS DRA certificate to your policy by using Microsoft Intune, see Step 3 in the Choose where apps can access enterprise data section of this topic.
segment.target: To add your EFS DRA certificate to your policy by using Microsoft Intune, see Step 3 in the Choose where apps can access enterprise data section of this topic.

segment.source: To manually create an EFS DRA certificate
segment.target: To manually create an EFS DRA certificate

segment.source: On a computer without an EFS DRA certificate installed, open a command prompt with elevated rights, and then navigate to where you want to store the certificate.
segment.target: On a computer without an EFS DRA certificate installed, open a command prompt with elevated rights, and then navigate to where you want to store the certificate.

segment.source: Run this command:
segment.target: Run this command:

segment.source: Where EFSRA is the name of the .cer and .pfx files that you want to create.
segment.target: Where EFSRA is the name of the .cer and .pfx files that you want to create.

segment.source: When prompted, type and confirm a password to help protect your new Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) file.
segment.target: When prompted, type and confirm a password to help protect your new Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) file.

segment.source: The EFSDRA.cer and EFSDRA.pfx files are created in the location you specified in Step 1.
segment.target: The EFSDRA.cer and EFSDRA.pfx files are created in the location you specified in Step 1.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Because these files can be used to decrypt any EDP file, you must protect them accordingly.
segment.target: Because these files can be used to decrypt any EDP file, you must protect them accordingly.

segment.source: We highly recommend storing them as a public key (PKI) on a smart card with strong protection, stored in a secured physical location.
segment.target: We highly recommend storing them as a public key (PKI) on a smart card with strong protection, stored in a secured physical location.

segment.source: Add your EFS DRA certificate to your EDP policy by using Step 3 of the Choose where apps can access enterprise data section of this topic.
segment.target: Add your EFS DRA certificate to your EDP policy by using Step 3 of the Choose where apps can access enterprise data section of this topic.

segment.source: To verify your data recovery certificate is correctly set up on an EDP client computer
segment.target: To verify your data recovery certificate is correctly set up on an EDP client computer

segment.source: Open an app on your protected app list, and then create and save a file so that it’s encrypted by EDP.
segment.target: Open an app on your protected app list, and then create and save a file so that it’s encrypted by EDP.

segment.source: Open a command prompt with elevated rights, navigate to where you stored the file you just created, and then run this command:
segment.target: Open a command prompt with elevated rights, navigate to where you stored the file you just created, and then run this command:

segment.source: Where filename is the name of the file you created in Step 1.
segment.target: Where filename is the name of the file you created in Step 1.

segment.source: Make sure that your data recovery certificate is listed in the Recovery Certificates list.
segment.target: Make sure that your data recovery certificate is listed in the Recovery Certificates list.

segment.source: To recover your data using the EFS DRA certificate in a test environment
segment.target: To recover your data using the EFS DRA certificate in a test environment

segment.source: Copy your EDP-encrypted file to a location where you have admin access.
segment.target: Copy your EDP-encrypted file to a location where you have admin access.

segment.source: Install the EFSDRA.pfx file, using your password.
segment.target: Install the EFSDRA.pfx file, using your password.

segment.source: Open a command prompt with elevated rights, navigate to the encrypted file, and then run this command:
segment.target: Open a command prompt with elevated rights, navigate to the encrypted file, and then run this command:

segment.source: Where encryptedfile.extension is the name of your encrypted file.
segment.target: Where encryptedfile.extension is the name of your encrypted file.

segment.source: For example, corporatedata.docx.
segment.target: For example, corporatedata.docx.

segment.source: Choose your optional EDP-related settings
segment.target: Choose your optional EDP-related settings

segment.source: After you've decided where your protected apps can access enterprise data on your network, you’ll be asked to decide if you want to add any optional EDP settings.
segment.target: After you've decided where your protected apps can access enterprise data on your network, you’ll be asked to decide if you want to add any optional EDP settings.

segment.source: To add your optional settings
segment.target: To add your optional settings

segment.source: Choose to set any or all of the optional EDP-related settings:
segment.target: Choose to set any or all of the optional EDP-related settings:

segment.source: Allow the user to decrypt data that was created or edited by the apps configured above.
segment.target: Allow the user to decrypt data that was created or edited by the apps configured above.

segment.source: Clicking Yes, or turning off this setting in Intune, lets your employees right-click to decrypt their protected app data, along with the option to decrypt data in the Save As box and the Save As file picker .
segment.target: Clicking Yes, or turning off this setting in Intune, lets your employees right-click to decrypt their protected app data, along with the option to decrypt data in the Save As box and the Save As file picker .

segment.source: Clicking No removes the Decrypt option and saves all data for protected apps as enterprise-encrypted.
segment.target: Clicking No removes the Decrypt option and saves all data for protected apps as enterprise-encrypted.

segment.source: Protect app content when the device is in a locked state for the apps configured above.
segment.target: Protect app content when the device is in a locked state for the apps configured above.

segment.source: Clicking Yes lets EDP help to secure protected app content when a mobile device is locked.
segment.target: Clicking Yes lets EDP help to secure protected app content when a mobile device is locked.

segment.source: We recommend turning this option on to help prevent data leaks from things such as email text that appears on the Lock screen of a Windows 10 Mobile phone.
segment.target: We recommend turning this option on to help prevent data leaks from things such as email text that appears on the Lock screen of a Windows 10 Mobile phone.

segment.source: Microsoft Intune: Optional EDP settings
segment.target: Microsoft Intune: Optional EDP settings

segment.source: Click Save Policy.
segment.target: Click Save Policy.
